That's great to hear that you're already incorporating yoga into your training! Yoga can be incredibly beneficial for improving flexibility, balance, and strength, all of which are essential for triathlon training.

The exercises and stretches I mentioned can certainly help improve your ankle mobility and strength, but considering your history of ankle issues, it's a good idea to take a more comprehensive approach. Given your specific needs, I would recommend exploring additional options to ensure you're adequately prepared for the demands of a sprint triathlon.

**Considerations:**

1. **See a Sports Medicine Specialist or Podiatrist**: A sports medicine specialist or podiatrist can assess your ankle mobility, strength, and biomechanics to identify any underlying issues that may be contributing to your ankle problems. They can provide customized exercises, stretches, and recommendations tailored to your specific needs.
2. **Custom Orthotics or Shoe Inserts**: If you have flat feet, high arches, or other foot mechanics issues, custom orthotics or shoe inserts can help redistribute pressure, reduce stress on your ankles, and improve your overall running efficiency.
3. **Gait Analysis**: A gait analysis can help identify any biomechanical issues in your running form that may be contributing to your ankle problems. This can be done by a sports medicine specialist, podiatrist, or a running coach.
4. **Strengthen Your Feet and Ankles**: In addition to the exercises I mentioned earlier, consider incorporating foot strengthening exercises, such as toe curls, toe spreads, and single-leg balances, to improve your overall foot and ankle strength.
5. **Gradual Progression**: Make sure to gradually increase your training volume, intensity, and frequency to give your ankles time to adapt to the demands of triathlon training.

**Integrating these Recommendations into Your Training:**

1. **Schedule Regular Check-Ins**: Set up regular check-ins with your yoga instructor, sports medicine specialist, or podiatrist to monitor your progress and adjust your training plan as needed.
2. **Incorporate Customized Exercises**: Add the exercises and stretches recommended by your specialist or podiatrist to your training routine, focusing on frequency, consistency, and proper form.
3. **Listen to Your Body**: Pay attention to your body and take rest days or modify your training as needed. If you experience any pain or discomfort, stop and consult with your specialist or podiatrist.

By taking a holistic approach to addressing your ankle mobility and incorporating these recommendations into your training, you'll be better prepared to tackle the demands of a sprint triathlon. Remember to be patient, consistent, and gentle with your body as you work towards your goals. Good luck!
